page.title: 02Chesterton - the village
page.content: Once just a small mining village, it has been much changed this century with the building of three housing estates. The largest of these sprawls down the Crackley Bank (the local word for hill) to the north of the old village centre. The Crackley estate is mainly council- owned property, although some of the houses belong to the National Coal Board. An older council estate to the south east of the village has a more pleasant aspect, and to the south west a private housing estate is still being added to. Between these three lies the old heart of Chesterton, a ribbon development along the "London Road", once a busy salt waggon and coaching route between Chester and the south. Here typical miners' cottages dating from the turn of the century may still be seen.
